title: WCAS HISTORY 492-0-20 Topics in History
class_attributes:
Attendance at 1st class mandatory

Graduate Students Only

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This seminar is an introduction to the most important figures, works, and debates in the history of Southeast Asia. It begins by considering the arguments for and against regional history and area studies. It then turns to an assessment of some of the most influential ideas in the study of the region, such as Oliver Wolters's notions of "localization," the "mandala" state, and the "man of prowess"; Anthony Reid's "Age of Commerce"; Clifford Geertz's formulation of the "theatre state"; James C. Scott's analysis of the "moral economy of the peasant" and "weapons of the weak"; J.S. Furnivall's notion of the "plural society"; and Thongchai Winichakul's conception of the "geo-body," among others. Students will gain a critical understanding of the historiography of modern Southeast Asia and its animating ideas.

descriptions.name: Evaluation Method
descriptions.value: Participation and Discussion; Response Papers; Final Paper
